message: Applications are open for the CBCF Summer '17 Internship Program!  Interns work in Congressional Black Caucus member offices, attend professional development events, and participate in leadership development projects. Housing and a stipend are provided. Visit ow.ly/EfNx308l9qQ to apply by March 31st.

It is an honor to again serve as a member of both the Capital Markets and Financial Institutions subcommittees.  Both of these subcommittees have wide-ranging jurisdiction over large parts of our banking system, from how banks do business on Wall Street to how community banks can write loans to small businesses.  A healthy, properly regulated banking system and mortgage market are critical to making sure families stay in their homes and our economy keeps humming so more and more Georgians can get back to work.  My commitment to my constituents is to use my position on these important subcommittees to work with anyone who has a good idea, regardless of political party, in order to create a more prosperous future.

Congressman David Scott (GA-13) was once again selected to serve as the Ranking Democratic member of the Subcommittee on Commodity Exchanges, Energy and Credit by the Democratic Members of the House Agriculture Committee.  The subcommittee‚Äôs jurisdiction includes oversight of commodity exchanges, including the Cobb County based InterContinental Exchange, one of the largest commodity exchanges in the world; as well as agricultural credit; rural development; energy; and rural electrification. Scott shared, "I look forward to working with all members of the committee ensuring that policies put forward work for my constituents, help promote growth, and allow Georgia farmers to continue to feed the world.‚Äù

Excited to honor 29 students from #GA13 tomorrow with congressional nominations to attend our U.S. Military Service academies. Thanks to the Marietta Daily Journal Douglas Neighbor Newspaper for recognizing students receiving nominations from Douglas County.

In the spirit of Black History Month, remembering key moments in black history, like the days of ‚ÄúBlack Wall Street,‚Äù is critical in shaping the future for African-Americans. In the early 1900s, the Greenwood district of Tulsa, Oklahoma was home to hundreds of black-owned business, many black multi-millionaires, an envied school system, and a remarkably high employment level. This affluent neighborhood was a microcosm of the American dream and a steeple for so many communities to strive towards.   In this great country of ours, many African-Americans, and more importantly African-American men, still feel the effects of unjust policies that systematically have left them behind. The unemployment rate for black men has often sat at twice that of the national average, and stands at 7.7% currently. In an effort to address these issues I am proud to have introduced legislation, H.R. 52, Jobs, On-the-Job 'Earn While You Learn' Training, and Apprenticeships for African-American Young Men Act. This bill requires the Department of Labor to request labor unions, general contractors, and businesses that will rebuild infrastructure, transportation systems, technology and computer networks, and energy distribution systems to actively recruit, hire, and provide on-the-job training to African American men ages 18 to 39. It is a responsibility of mine to ensure that everyone in this country can take part in economic expansion and I will continue to work on behalf of all of my constituents to help those in need.
On this day in black history, the U.S. House of Representatives passed the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by a vote of 290-130. #BlackHistoryMonth

Flashback Friday: Honored to keynote the Atlanta Veterans Benefits Administration (VBA), U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs Regional Office's #BlackHistoryMonth program yesterday. We remembered the achievements of Crispus Attucks, Henry Flipper, the Tuskegee Airmen, Colin Powell and many others. In battle after battle - from Vicksburg and Bull Run, to Gettysburg and Appomattox - Black members of the U.S. Armed Forces have been fiercely loyal, vigilant fighters, and strong defenders of our nation at home and abroad. What a glorious history.
Enjoyed meetings in Washington this week with leaders from the Georgia Schools Nurses Association, Atlanta Realtors Association and Douglas County's District Attorney's Office.

On this day in black history, Morehouse College was organized 150 years ago in 1867. Happy Founder's Day Morehouse College.

As we continue to celebrate Black History Month, we remember those who have made opportunities possible for so many, like George Washington Carver (1864-1943). In 1890, Carver enrolled in Simpson College in Indianola, Iowa, where he studied Art. He later transferred to Iowa State to study agriculture, where he earned his Master‚Äôs degree by 1896. After accepting an offer from Booker T. Washington, Carver then moved to Alabama where he served as the head of the Agricultural Department at Tuskegee Institute (a historically black college, HBCU). Carver‚Äôs research at Tuskegee was innovative in improving efficiency for farmers. Carver became a figure head in agriculture and an icon for the black community.  Carver‚Äôs contributions to society can still be felt in places like our home state of Georgia. Even with Carver‚Äôs success in agriculture and at an HBCU, there is still more to be done. I am proud to be working to address these issues by introducing legislation in Congress, H.R. 51, the Funding for Student Scholarships for the 1890s Land-Grant African-American Colleges and Universities Act. This bill would establish and provide funding for a grant program through the U.S. Department of Agriculture for scholarships for students who attend historically black colleges and universities established under the Second Morrill Act of 1890. It would allow the USDA to award scholarships to students who want to attend these colleges and intend to pursue a career in the food and agricultural sciences.   Our commitment to the success of our young people is always a priority in hopes for American‚Äôs bright future. I will continue to do the work necessary to ensure these possibilities.

As the month of April concludes today, let us never forget the importance of Sexual Assault Awareness Month (SAAM). Every 98 seconds, another American falls victim to a sexual assault, yet many perpetrators walk free.  It is imperative that we protect survivors while also finding ways to prevent these despicable attacks from happening in the future. We celebrate SAAM to show that we, like many others, will speak out against sexual assault and continue to do the work to fight such devastating crimes.    In Congress I have been a longtime supporter of the Violence Against Women Act and continue to work to ensure adequate funding for programs that are successful in supporting survivors and preventing assaults.   Additionally, I have signed on to legislation such as the Pet and Women Safety Act to protect those affected by sexual assault and domestic violence who might delay their departure from dangerous relationships out of concern for the fate of their pet. Earlier this month, I signed on to a letter to request funding for the Sexual Assault Kit Initiative to combat the high numbers of sexual assault kits not being tested.   This April, I am reaffirming my commitment to be an advocate of sexual assault awareness and prevention as I continue to serve the constituents of Georgia‚Äôs 13th Congressional District.

Congratulations to our 2017 Congressional Art Competition First Place winner Christian Alexander of Langston Hughes High School! As the top winner, Christian‚Äôs work will be displayed in the U.S. Capitol for 1 year, along with the first place artwork from other congressional districts around the U.S.  He also won a $12,000 scholarship from the Savannah College of Art and Design; $12,000 scholarship from the Art Institute of Atlanta; a $1,000 prize; and round-trip airfare for 2 from Southwest Airlines to attend the ribbon-cutting ceremony for the Capitol exhibit in Washington, D.C.

We cannot turn our backs on the least of these in our country.  And Congress must not let these draconian cuts happen.  They are wrong for Georgia and wrong for America.

The updated CBO score confirms what we already knew, the American Health Care Act (AHCA) is a cruel attack on the American people and it demonstrates the reckless approach Republicans have taken to reforming 1/5 of our economy.   Rather than working with Democrats to improve the Affordable Care Act (ACA), Republicans bulldozed ahead, without waiting to find out what the consequences would be for the American people. Now, it is clear that their bill slashes $834 billion from Medicaid, a program that provides health care to some of our most vulnerable citizens; increases costs for older Americans; and risks coverage for 1.8 million Georgians under 65 who have a pre-existing condition.  After 10 years, 23 million more Americans will be uninsured under the AHCA.  And 51 million people under 65 would be uninsured in 10 years, versus 28 million under the ACA.  The CBO also estimates that, in some states, people with preexisting conditions might not be able to buy coverage ‚Äúat all‚Äù.  Out-of-pocket spending on maternity care, mental health, and substance abuse services could increase by thousands of dollars a year for people who live in states that waive essential health benefits.  The CBO score makes plain that the Republican bill to replace and repeal Obamacare is a dangerous bill for our nation‚Äôs health care system.  That is why I am dedicated to fighting to protect the ACA; improving it, so that more Americans benefit; and opposing the Republicans‚Äô damaging health care proposal.
On this #MemorialDay, we must remember that we are the land of the free because of the brave. Today we honor those who laid down their lives in the name of liberty.

It doesn‚Äôt take a historian to remember the catastrophe that was our economy after Wall Street caused it to come tumbling down during the recession. Have Republicans in the House forgotten that nearly 9 million people lost their jobs in 2008 and 2009 alone, especially impacting African Americans who to this day are experiencing double the national average in unemployment rates?  Millions of families saw their homes foreclosed on or go underwater.  And, $11 trillion in household wealth went up in smoke, sweeping away the hard-earned retirement savings of middle-class Americans.    The Republicans‚Äô #WrongChoiceAct will drag Americans back to the depths of the financial crisis. We will fight them.
Today I spoke on the House Floor in strong opposition to the Republicans‚Äô ‚ÄúWrong Choice Act,‚Äù which would undo safeguards for American consumers implemented after the Great Recession.

On this day in 1967, Loving v. Virginia was decided. The landmark ruling by the U.S. Supreme Court struck down laws prohibiting interracial marriage, including voiding a Georgia law, enacted in 1750, that had made it unlawful for any nonwhite person to marry any white person. #LovingDay

Let us lift up in prayer those who were injured today, and pray for the healing of our nation as well as we try to bridge the gaps that divide us. While our hearts are understandably heavy in the aftermath of this shooting, and our minds struggle to find reason among the madness, let us not grow weary or faint or further apart.  Instead let us find strength and unity in our shared values, for America is stronger together.

Happy Father's Day from our family to yours! On this day, we celebrate fathers and their boundless contributions to our families and in our communities. Being a father is one of the most honorable and rewarding roles anyone could ever play. My two daughters, Dayna and Marcye, have taught me so much about the man I am today. I couldn‚Äôt be more grateful to have such an amazing and supportive family that is patient, kind, and uplifting.

#ICYMI: watch my remarks from today's Financial Services Committee markup:  We can't remain silent because as long as this Russia investigation is going on with our president, it is the American people who are suffering.  We have 21 veterans committing suicide every day, but no mention of that.  We have an opioid crisis of resounding consequences for the future of our young generation.  Nobody is talking about that.  It has to stop.  It‚Äôs gone on too long. We in this committee, all we're asking is for Treasury to present us with this information and let us as Members of Congress stand up for the American people.  They deserve for us to be talking about jobs, job training, and the crises that are moving throughout this nation. And so I hope we can do this in a bipartisan way and make this nation proud.

Today I called for more than a nebulous answer on when the U.S. will risk defaulting on its debt obligations during the House Financial Services Committee hearing with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. Non-answers inject uncertainty in the markets.  Sec. Mnuchin also failed to commit to sending the committee and Congress regular updates on when the U.S. will default without an increase in the debt ceiling by Congress.  Leading up to the 2015 debt limit showdown, Mnuchin‚Äôs predecessor, Jack Lew, sent several letters to Congress on July 29, September 10, October 1 and October 15.

Now, what‚Äôs important is for Democrats and Republicans to sit down together and realize, and I‚Äôm the first one to say it: Obamacare is not perfect. There are changes to be made. Now we can move forward with a plan.

I am very upset by the President‚Äôs actions today on #DACA, and I plan to meet with him to get him to change his mind on this decision.  It is unconscionable to punish children for the actions of their parents. These are children and young adults who were brought to the U.S. as small kids, and they know no other home but here in America.  They attend schools, hold jobs and are valuable members of our communities across the nation.  They are American through and through, and deserve the same respect, dignity and chance to succeed that the rest of us hope for ourselves. #ProtectDREAMers

#TBT Honored to host a briefing yesterday with PCOS Challenge to raise awareness for Polycystic Ovary Syndrome. The most common cause of female infertility, #PCOS affects 5-10 million American women and girls, costs the U.S. healthcare system roughly $4.3 billion each year, and has no known cure. That's why I sponsored H. Res. 495, which calls on Congress to recognize the seriousness of PCOS with support for further research to find improved treatment, care options and a cure for PCOS. The bipartisan resolution also designates September as #PCOSAwarenessMonth.

#OTD 40 years ago, Georgia‚Äôs own President Jimmy Carter signed the Food and Agriculture Act of 1977.  This law paved the way for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), which is so important in our efforts to reduce poverty and hunger in America. Last year, 1 out of every 6 Georgians received SNAP assistance, with over 70% helping families with children. We must continue to do everything we can to fight hunger, especially child hunger, by investing in programs like SNAP that have proven to be effective in making sure our children have the food they need to thrive in our great country.

#DYK: 40,000 veterans commit suicide each year? This is a national crisis, but it is more than that. It is a national tragedy and an American national shame.  Our soldiers go where they are commanded to go. And when we bring them back home, the level of treatment that many of them are getting, and even not getting, is, again, a national tragedy and a national shame.  That's why I joined several Members of Congress earlier this week to give remarks to awaken us to what I believe is, and should be, the number one issue facing this Nation: taking care of our veterans. #SuicidePreventionMonth

HUD Secretary Ben Carson should be at the forefront, fighting to protect vital programs like the Community Development Block Grant (CDBG), which has created and retained 386,000 jobs for low and moderate income persons. It has benefited 42 million people through public improvements for seniors, veterans, children and people with disabilities. And it has helped 133 million low and moderate income persons through public services like employment training. Secretary Carson needs to stand up and fight back in this Administration because it needs help when it comes to dealing with hurting Americans. Compassion alone won't do it!

"President Trump has spent the week recklessly rolling back coverage for birth control for millions of women, signing an executive order that will increase costs for sicker, older Americans, and ensuring that Americans will pay significantly more for health insurance coverage next year.   ‚ÄúEnough is enough. It is time for the partisan games to end. I call on both my Democratic and Republican colleagues to work together to ensure Americans continue to have access to comprehensive, affordable healthcare. Congress should be working to ensure that the thousands of families in Georgia with PeachCare don't have a lapse in coverage & can rest easy knowing that if their child gets sick, they can get the care they need.
